Q9.text: Socrates || demonstrates || in || many || ways || his || disagreement || with || the || way || Meno || asks || about || the || subject || virtue. || Such || a || disagreement || is || not || just || a || critique || against || Meno || but || also || against || the || debate || between || physics || and || politics. || The || Milesians || (physical || scientists) || argue || that || one || becomes || virtuous || by || nature || (physis). || The || Sophists || (political || scientists) || defend || the || position || that || one || becomes || virtuous || in || society || (polis) || either || by || teaching || or || by || practice. || In || paragraph || 2, || Socrates || tells || us || that || his || disagreement || is || not || just || a || matter || of || personal || opinion || but || is || a || shared || disagreement || among || Ateneans, || who || will || reply || to || the || Lasallian || Meno's || question || in || this || manner: || “Stranger, || I || seem || to || be || in || danger || of || your || thinking || me || to || be || someone || who || is || blessed || -- || to || know || about || virtue, || whether || it || is || something || teachable || or || not || teachable, || that || I || happen || not || to || know || at || all || what || that || thing || virtue || itself || is.” || What || this || reply || suggests || is || that || Meno's || question || wrongly || presupposes || not || only || a || general || knowledge || but || also || a || general || understanding || of || the || subject || being || debated. || But || no || Atenean || will || make || such || an || uncritical || assumption. || Instead, || every || Atenean || will || assume || general || ignorance || to || avoid || baseless || disagreement || or || mistaken || agreement. || To || reinforce || this || claim, || Socrates || points || to || his || own || ignorance || in || paragraph || 3: || “And || I || myself, || Meno, || am || in || this || condition, || too. || I || share || the || poverty || of || my || fellow || Ateneans || in || this || matter || and || blame || myself || for || not || knowing || about || virtue || at || all.” || Because || of || the || popular || narrative || that || the || god || of || truth, || Apollo, || through || the || oracle || at || Delphi, || has || proclaimed || that || “No || one || is || wiser || than || Socrates,” || Socrates's || claim || of || ignorance || comes || as || a || surprise || to || Meno, || who, || in || paragraph || 4 || asks: || “But || do || you, || Socrates, || truly || not || know || what || virtue || is, || and || is || this || really || what || we || should || report || about || you || back || home?” || With || this || challenge, || Meno || sees || an || intellectual || win || for || Lasallians || against || Ateneans, || whose || patroness || is || the || goddess || of || wisdom, || Athena. || To || force || Meno || to || give || up || his || erroneous || question || and || ask || the || right || question || instead, || in || paragraph || 5 || Socrates || exaggerates || the || extent || of || ignorance: || “Not || only || that, || comrade, || but || also || that || I || never || yet || happened || to || meet || anyone || else || who, || in || my || opinion, || did || know.” || Against || this || exaggerated || ignorance, || Meno || is || baited || into || protesting || (in || paragraph || 6): || “What? || You || didn't || happen || to || meet || Gorgias || when || he || was || here?” || and || again || (in || paragraph || 8): || “Really || -- || did || he || not || seem || to || you || to || know?” || Meno || insists || that || his || teacher || Gorgias || knows || about || the || subject. || By || extension, || the || student, || Meno, || also || knows || about || the || subject. || Consistent || with || his || critique || of || Meno's || presupposition, || in || paragraph || 9 || Socrates || did || not || immediately || accept || but || verifies || Meno's || claim || instead: || “I'm || not || a || very || good || rememberer, || Meno, || so || I'm || not || able || to || say || at || present || how || he || seemed || to || me || then. || But, || perhaps, || he || did || know, || and || you || know || what || he || used || to || say. || Then, || remind || me || how || he || said || it. || Or, || if || you || wish, || speak || yourself, || for || you || surely || share || his || opinion.” || By || letting || Meno || promote || his || teacher || and || himself, || Socrates || shifts || the || lesson || away || from || the || erroneous || to || the || correct.

Q15.text: First, then, if it's the virtue of a man you want, it's easy to say that this is the virtue of a man: to be sufficient to carry on the affairs of the city and while carrying them on to do well by his friends and harm to his enemies and to take care that he not suffer any such thing himself.

selected: First, then, if it's the virtue of a man you want, it's easy to say that this is the virtue of a man: to be sufficient to carry on the affairs of the city and while carrying them on to do well by his friends and harm to his enemies and to take care that he not suffer any such thing himself.

Q16.text: And if it's the virtue of a woman you want, that's not hard to go through, in that she needs to manage the household well, conserving what is inside and being obedient to her man.

selected: And if it's the virtue of a woman you want, that's not hard to go through, in that she needs to manage the household well, conserving what is inside and being obedient to her man.

Q17.text: And the virtue of a child is different, both female and male, and of an elderly man, and, if you want, of a freeman or, if you want, of a slave.

selected: And the virtue of a child is different, both female and male, and of an elderly man, and, if you want, of a freeman or, if you want, of a slave.

Q18.text: Well then, courage seems to me, at any rate, to be a virtue, and moderation, and wisdom, and magnificence, and a great many others.

selected: Well then, courage seems to me, at any rate, to be a virtue, and moderation, and wisdom, and magnificence, and a great many others.

Q19.text: And there are a great many other virtues, so that there is no difficulty in speaking about what virtue is. For according to each activity and each time of life relative to each task for each of us there is a virtue.

selected: And there are a great many other virtues, so that there is no difficulty in speaking about what virtue is. For according to each activity and each time of life relative to each task for each of us there is a virtue.

Q22.text: Socrates || demonstrates || in || many || ways || his || disagreement || with || Meno's || initial || interpretation || which || makes || the || Socratic || question || 'what || is || virtue?' || ask || for || examples. || In || paragraph || 13, || Socrates || tells || Meno: || “I || seem || to || have || hit || upon || some || great || good || fortune, || Meno, || if, || while || seeking || one || virtue || I || have || discovered || a || sort || of || swarm || of || virtues || gathered || about || you.” || This || is || a || sarcastic || comment || from || Socrates || as || evidenced || by || his || follow-up || in || paragraph || 17: || “And || so || too, || surely || about || the || virtues: || even || if || they || are || many || and || of || all || sorts, || still || they || all || have || some || one || and || the || same || form || through || which || they || are || virtues || and || upon || which || one || In || paragraph || 53, || Socrates || again || complains || when || Meno || again || commits || the || same || mistake: || “Again, || Meno, || we || have || suffered || the || same || thing. || Although || seeking || one, || we || have || found || many || virtues, || but || in || another || way || than || we || did || just || now. || But || the || one || which || exists || throughout || all || of || these || we || are || not || able || to || find || out.” || Socrates || advises || Meno || in || paragraph || 113 || to || “stop || making || many || out || of || one, || as || those || who || like || to || jeer || say || each || time || about || those || who || break || something, || but || rather, || leaving || it || whole || and || healthy.” || The || complaint || and || the || advice || are || clarified || in || a || conclusion || Socrates || offers || in || paragraph || 177: || “Therefore, || my || good || man, || while || what || virtue || is || as || a || whole || is || still || being || sought, || do || not || suppose || that || in || answering || through || its || pieces || you || will || in || any || way || clarify || it, || or || anything || else, || by || speaking || of || it || in || this || same || way, || but || consider || that || you || will || be || in || need || again || of || the || very || same || question.” || In || other || words, || what || parts || make || up || a || whole || can || only || be || recognized || when || one || knows || the || whole || to || which || they || are || parts.

parts: How can fitness routines improve gradually?

What are examples of fitness routines?
include strength training, cardio exercises, flexibility workouts, balance drills, and high-intensity interval training
What is the essence of fitness routines?
The essence of fitness routines is the intentional organization of bodily exercises into a consistent practice aimed at sustaining or enhancing physical condition (Harvard Health, 2024).
is the intentional organization of bodily exercises into a consistent practice aimed at sustaining or enhancing physical condition

Q29.text: In || paragraph || 42, || Meno's || reply || to || the || Socratic || question || is || based || on || the || condition || that || Socrates || confirms || with || certainty: || “What || else || than || to || be || able || to || rule || over || human || beings || ‑‑ || if || indeed || you || are || seeking || some || one || thing || concerning || all || of || them?” || That || Meno || is || able || to || grasp || this || condition || only || to || let || go || again || is || a || source || of || constant || frustration || as || Socrates || complains || in || paragraph || 53: || “Again, || Meno, || we || have || suffered || the || same || thing. || Although || seeking || one, || we || have || found || many || virtues, || but || in || another || way || than || we || did || just || now. || But || the || one || which || exists || throughout || all || of || these || we || are || not || able || to || find || out.” || Refusing || to || give || up || on || Meno, || Socrates || brings || in || a || hypothetical || partner || in || a || conversation || on || shape || to || elaborate || the || function || of || the || Socratic || question. || In || paragraph || 65, || that || hypothetical || partner || will || argue: || “We || always || arrive || at || many, || but || this || is || not || what || I'm || seeking. || But || since || you || address || these || many || by || some || one || name || and || you || say || of || none || of || them || that || they || are || not || shape, || even || those || that || are || opposite || to || one || another, || what || is || this || that || comprises || the || round || or || the || straight, || which || indeed || you || name || shape, || and || you || affirm || that || the || round || is || no || more || shape || than || the || straight?” || Or || is || this || not || the || way || that || you || speak? || Meno's || second || reply || continues || to || be || founded || on || the || condition || articulated || above, || a || promise || to || Socrates || which || is: || “in || saying || about || virtue || as || a || whole, || what || it || is, || and || stop || making || many || out || of || one, || as || those || who || like || to || jeer || say || each || time || about || those || who || break || something, || but || rather, || leaving || it || whole || and || healthy, || tell || me || what || virtue || is. || The || patterns, || at || any || rate, || you || have || got || from || me.” || When || Meno || forgets || this || promise, || Socrates || reminds || Meno || in || paragraph || 171: || “Because || just || now || when || you || were || requested || by || me || not || to || shatter || virtue || or || to || change || it || into || a || small || coin, || and || I || gave || you || patterns || in || accordance || with || which || it || was || to || be || answered, || yet || you || paid || no || attention || to || this || and || tell || me || that || virtue || is || to || be || able || to || provide || good || things || for || oneself || along || with || justice. || And || this, || you || declare, || is || a || piece || of || virtue?”

Q30.text: How + auxiliary verb + subject + main verb + adverb || process || not only a general knowledge but also a general understanding of the subject being debated || What + auxiliary verb + subject + main verb || concrete expressions || what parts make up a whole can only be recognized when one knows the whole to which they are parts || What + auxiliary verb + subject + main verb || essence || the meaning of virtue || What || is || change, || being, || motion, || time, || space, || mind, || matter? || What || is || time? || If || no || one || asks || me, || I || know; || if || I || wish || to || explain || it || to || someone || who || asks, || I || do || not || know. || Philosophy || consists || largely || in || asking || these || questions || about || what || I || already || “know.” || Of || course, || I || know || what || I || mean || by || “I,” || “self,” || “being,” || “real,” || “mind,” || “matter,” || “change,” || “time,” || “thing,” || and || so || on. || That || is, || if || no || one || asks || me, || I || know; || I || simply || inhabit || their || obviousness, || their || commonplace-ness. || This || kind || of || obviousness, || however, || is || really || a || very || derivative || realm; || it || is || a || realm || in || which || assumptions, || conceptual || and || linguistic || schemes, || objectified || systems || of || thought, || social || and || cultural || custom, || have || interpreted || themselves || between || reflection || and || original || experience. || What || I || know || is || what || “everybody || knows,” || and || hence || what || nobody || really || knows. || consist || so || much || in || a || set || of || formulated || answers || as || it || does || in || the || entering || into || a || certain || kind || of || question || the || awakening || out || of || acceptance || turning || away || from || what || “everybody || knows” || towards || the || real || as || it || is || delivered || to || my || lived || consciousness

Q32.text: In || paragraph || 3, || Marcel || (1950) || tells || us || that || reflection || is || "nothing || other || than || attention || ... || directed || towards || a || small || break || in || the || daily || chain || of || habit" || or || towards || an || obstacle || in || a || "living || personal || experience." || Marcel || (1950) || explains || this || by || means || of || examples, || "with || each || offering || a || deeper || view || than || the || previous || one || of || how || a || person || reflects," || observes || Ramon || Sunico || (2019) || in || "Reading || Marcel: || 3 || Easy || Pieces || for || Beginners." || In || the || first || example, || reflection || is || triggered || when || my || daily || chain || of || habit, || which || is || "the || act || of || putting || my || hand || in || my || pocket || and || that || of || taking || out || my || watch," || is || broken || by || the || discovery || that || "my || watch || is || not || there." || The || break || "arrests || my || attention" || because || there || is || "the || notion || that || a || valuable || object || may || be || lost" || and || there || is || "a || feeling || of || disquiet" || that || can || only || be || dispelled || when || the || broken || chain || is || resolved. || This || attention, || therefore, || is || not || "the || kind || of || purely || abstract || speculation || which, || of || its || very || nature, || can || have || no || practical || outcome." || This || mental || effort || is || exercised || on || "something || real, || something || valuable," || never || on || "things || that || are || not || worth || the || trouble || of || reflecting || about." || It || is || also || "a || personal || act, || and || an || act || which || nobody || else || would || have || been || able || to || undertake || in || my || place, || or || on || my || behalf." || "To || reflect," || according || to || Marcel || (1950), || "is || to || ask || oneself || how || such || a || break || can || have || occurred: || When || was || the || watch || last || in || my || possession? || "I || remember || having || looked || at || the || time || just || after || breakfast; || therefore || at || that || moment || everything || was || still || all || right. || Between || then || and || now || something || must || have || happened || to || the || watch. || ... || Was || there || perhaps || a || hole || in || my || pocket? || I || look || at || my || pocket || and || discover || that || there || is || no || hole. || I || continue || with || my || task || of || alert || recapitulation. || ... || I || succeed || in || recalling || the || fact || that || there || was || a || moment || when || I || put || the || watch || down || on || a || table; || I || shall || go, || of || course, || to || see || whether || it || is || still || on || the || table; || and || there || the || watch || still || is." || To || reflect || is || to || "go || back || in || time || until || I || recall || the || moment || when || the || watch || was || last || in || my || possession." || Similar || to || the || exercise || of || biographers || and || historiographers, || reflection || is, || as || Sunico || (2019) || interprets || it, || "remembering" || (paragraph || 2) || or || "thinking || of || what || one || owns || by || noticing || it || is || lost" || (paragraph || 6). || Reflection || stops || when || it || "has || carried || out || its || task, || and || the || problem || is || solved," || which, || in || this || example, || is || when || "I || recall || the || moment || when || the || watch || was || last || in || my || possession." || Using || Marcel's || (1950) || metaphor, || reflection || is || a || ferryman, || which || allows || a || traveler || to || continue || even || when || the || bridge || that || normally || allows || him || to || cross || the || river || has || been || carried || away || by || a || flood.

Q33.text: In || the || second || example || (paragraphs || 4-5), || Marcel || (1950) || tells || us || that || reflection || is || not || just || the || asking || subject || attending || to || an || object || one || owns || by || noticing || it || is || lost, || but || also || about || the || asking || subject || attending || to || its || "inner || life," || that || is || the || subject || treated || objectively. || In || this || example, || reflection || is || triggered || when || my || daily || chain || of || habit, || which || is || "to || think || of || myself, || up || to || the || present, || as || a || truthful || and || trustworthy || person," || is || broken || by || the || realization || that || "I || let || myself || be || drawn || into || telling || him || something || which || is || an || actual || lie." || The || break || is || arresting || because || something || valuable || may || be || lost, || specifically, || "the || man || I || thought || I || was." || To || reflect, || according || to || Marcel || (1950), || is || "to || get || a || grip || on || myself," || to || "face || the || fact || of || this || lie" || and || ask || myself || "how || was || it || possible || for || me || to || tell || such || a || whopper? || More || specifically, || to || reflect || is || to || answer || these || questions: || "But || then || what || importance || ought || I || to || attach || to || this || lie? || Am || I || forced || to || conclude || that || I || am || not || the || man || I || thought || I || was? || And, || from || another || point || of || view, || what || attitude || ought || I || to || take || up || towards || this || act || of || mine? || Ought || I || to || confess || the || lie || to || my || friend, || or || on || the || other || hand || would || I || make || myself || ridiculous || by || doing || so? || But || perhaps || I || ought || to || make || myself || ridiculous, || to || let || my || friend || laugh || at || me, || as || a || sort || of || punishment || for || having || told || him || the || lie || in || the || first || place? || To || reflect || is || to || make || an || act || of || "readjustment || on || my || part." || Similar || to || the || exercise || of || psychoanalysts, || reflection || is, || as || Sunico || (2019) || interprets || it, || "paying || attention || to || one’s || own || thoughts || " || (paragraph || 2).

Q34.text: In || the || third || example || (paragraphs || 6-7), || Marcel || (1950) || gives || an || easier || access || to || the || notion || of || reflection || at || the || properly || philosophical || (that || is, || “broader” || and || “more || intimate”) || level. || In || this || example, || reflection || is || triggered || when || my || daily || chain || of || habit, || which || is || having || “somebody || of || whom || I || was || fond,” || is || broken || by || his || disappointing || behaviour. || The || break || is || arresting || because || something || valuable || may || be || lost, || specifically, || our || friendship. || To || reflect || in || this || example, || according || to || Marcel || (1950), || is || “to || acknowledge || that || he || is || not || the || man || I || believed || him || to || be” || (paragraph || 6). || Sunico || (2019) || interprets || this || reflection || as || “thinking || of || what || one || owns || by || noticing || it || is || lost” || (paragraph || 6). || In || other || words, || in || this || case, || to || reflect || is || to || think || that || once || I || had || a || friend, || who || is || not || a || friend || anymore. || Marcel || (1950), || however, || tells || us || that || “it || may || be || that || the || process || of || reflection || does || not || halt || there || [the || first || stage]” || (paragraph || 6). || To || reflect || is || also || to || “call || my || own || position || into || question”: || ‘Was || this || act || of || mine || really || so || very || different || from || the || act || which || today || I || feel || inclined || to || judge || so || severely? || But || in || that || case || am || I || in || any || position || to || condemn || my || friend?’ || (paragraph || 6). || Sunico || (2019) || interprets || reflection || here || as || thinking || about || “what || owning || means” || (paragraph || 6). || One || does || not || just || think || of || having || a || friend, || but || must || also || ask || oneself || about || what || having || a || friend || means. || Is || a || friend || no || different || from || any || object || I || possess, || which || I || can || easily || let || go || once || it || fails || to || meet || my || expectations? || Marcel || (1950) || pushes || the || questioning || further. || To || reflect || is || to || ask: || “But || what || does || ‘myself’ || mean || here? || The || point || is || that || I || have || been || forced || to || ask || myself || what || I || am || worth, || how || true || I || ring. || So || far || I || had || taken || myself, || so || to || speak, || for || granted, || I || quite || naturally || thought || of || myself || as || qualified || to || judge || and || eventually || to || condemn. || Or || perhaps || even || that || is || not || quite || the || case: || I || used || to || behave || or, || what || comes || to || the || same || thing, || I || used || to || talk || like || a || man || qualified || to || judge || others. || In || my || heart || of || hearts, || I || did || not || really || think || of || myself || as || such || a || man” || (paragraph || 6). || Sunico || (2019) || interprets || reflection || here || as || asking || oneself || “who || one || is” || (paragraph || 6). || Again, || Marcel || (1950) || tells || us || that || the || “process || of || reflection || may || terminate” || (paragraph || 6). || Reflection || stops || when || it || “has || carried || out || its || task, || and || the || problem || is || solved.” || In || this || example, || this || is || when || I || am || forced || to || realize || that || “on || the || one || hand, || I || am || now || able || to || communicate || at || a || broader || level || with || myself, || since || I || have, || as || it || were || introduced || the || self || that || committed || the || dubious || act || to || the || self || that || did || not || hesitate || to || set || itself || up || as || the || harsh || judge || of || such || acts || in || others; || and || on || the || other || hand, || I || am || now || able || to || enter || into || far || more || intimate || communication || with || my || friend, || since || between || us || there || no || longer || stands || that || barrier || which || separates || the || judge || on || the || bench || from || the || accused || man || in || the || dock” || (paragraph || 7). || Sunico || (2019) || interprets || reflection || here || as || studying || “the || very || value || of || one’s || existence” || or || as || “consider[ing] || the || very || meaning || and || value || of || an || existence || where || one || is || and || owns || at || the || same || time” || (paragraph || 6).

Q35.text: thinking || of || what || one || owns || by || noticing || it || is || lost || thinking || about || what || owning || means || asking || oneself || who || one || is || considering || the || very || meaning || and || value || of || an || existence || where || one || is || and || owns || at || the || same || time || pure || spontaneity || a || manifestation || of || animality || the || harmonious || functioning || of || a || certain || number || of || organs || something || purely || and || merely || critical || it || not || only || puts || a || bridle || on || the || vital || impulses, || it || freezes || them || we || cannot || even || conceive || by || what || sort || of || miracle || reflection || could || be || grafted || on || mere || animality || its || centre || outside || itself || one || of || the || ways || in || which || life || manifests || itself || one || of || life’s || ways || of || rising || from || one || level || to || another || human || life || is || always || centered || on || some || goal || beyond || itself || reflection || is || an || essential || ingredient || of || human || life, || for || in || human || beings || life || becomes || aware || of || itself || Reflection || naturally || arises || when || some || obstacle || interrupts || life’s || normal || routine || and || one || is || forced || to || pay || closer || attention || to || his || or || her || experience || transforms || our || life || from || something || simply || driven || by || passions || and || desires || into || a || life || lived || by || conscious || choice || and || direction || provides || a || richness || of || experience || that || would || be || missing || if || I || lived || without || being || aware || of || my || thoughts, || desires, || feelings, || choices, || and || other || mental || acts || if || I || lived || without || being || aware || of || my || inner || self
